column1: _THE PEA-FIELDS_     These are the fields of light, and laughing air,       And yellow butterflies, and foraging bees,       And whitish, wayward blossoms winged as these,     And pale green tangles like a seamaid’s hair.
column2: Pale, pale the blue, but pure beyond compare,       And pale the sparkle of the far-off seas,       A-shimmer like these fluttering slopes of peas,     And pale the open landscape everywhere.
column3: From fence to fence a perfumed breath exhales       O’er the bright pallor of the well-loved fields,--     My fields of Tantramar in summer-time;       And, scorning the poor feed their pasture yields,     Up from the bushy lots the cattle climb,       To gaze with longing through the grey, mossed rails.
column4: _THE MOWING_     This is the voice of high midsummer’s heat.
column5: The rasping vibrant clamour soars and shrills       O’er all the meadowy range of shadeless hills,     As if a host of giant cicadae beat     The cymbals of their wings with tireless feet,       Or brazen grasshoppers with triumphing note       From the long swath proclaimed the fate that smote     The clover and timothy-tops and meadowsweet.
column6: The crying knives glide on; the green swath lies.
column7: And all noon long the sun, with chemic ray,       Seals up each cordial essence in its cell,     That in the dusky stalls, some winter’s day,       The spirit of June, here prisoned by his spell,       May cheer the herds with pasture memories.
column8: _BURNT LANDS_     On other fields and other scenes the morn       Laughs from her blue,--but not such fields are these,       Where comes no cheer of summer leaves and bees,     And no shade mitigates the day’s white scorn.
column9: These serious acres vast no groves adorn;       But giant trunks, bleak shapes that once were trees,       Tower naked, unassuaged of rain or breeze,     Their stern grey isolation grimly borne.
column10: The months roll over them, and mark no change.
column11: But when Spring stirs, or Autumn stills, the year,       Perchance some phantom leafage rustles faint     Through their parched dreams,--some old-time notes ring strange,       When in his slender treble, far and clear,       Reiterates the rain-bird his complaint.
column12: _THE CLEARING_     Stumps, and harsh rocks, and prostrate trunks all charred,       And gnarled roots naked to the sun and rain,--       They seem in their grim stillness to complain,     And by their plaint the evening peace is jarred.
column13: These ragged acres fire and the axe have scarred,       And many summers not assuaged their pain.
column14: In vain the pink and saffron light, in vain     The pale dew on the hillocks stripped and marred!
column15: But here and there the waste is touched with cheer       Where spreads the fire-weed like a crimson flood     And venturous plumes of golden-rod appear;       And round the blackened fence the great boughs lean     With comfort; and across the solitude       The hermit’s holy transport peals serene.
column16: _THE SUMMER POOL_     This is a wonder-cup in Summer’s hand.
column17: Sombre, impenetrable, round its rim       The fir-trees bend and brood.
column18: The noons o’erbrim     The windless hollow of its iris’d strand     With mote-thick sun and water-breathings bland.
column19: Under a veil of lilies lurk and swim       Strange shapes of presage in a twilight dim,     Unwitting heirs of light and life’s command.
column20: Blind in their bondage, of no change they dream,       But the trees watch in grave expectancy       The spell fulfils,--and swarms of radiant flame,     Live jewels, above the crystal dart and gleam,       Nor guess the sheen beneath their wings to be       The dark and narrow regions whence they came.
column21: _BUCKWHEAT_     This smell of home and honey on the breeze,       This shimmer of sunshine woven in white and pink       That comes, a dream from memory’s visioned brink,     Sweet, sweet and strange across the ancient trees,--     It is the buckwheat, boon of the later bees,       Its breadths of heavy-headed bloom appearing       Amid the blackened stumps of this high clearing,     Freighted with cheer of comforting auguries.
column22: But when the blunt, brown grain and red-ripe sheaves,     Brimming the low log barn beyond the eaves,       Crisped by the first frost, feel the thresher’s flail,     Then flock the blue wild-pigeons in shy haste       All silently down Autumn’s amber trail,     To glean at dawn the chill and whitening waste.
column23: _THE CICADA IN THE FIRS_     Charm of the vibrant, white September sun--       How tower the firs to take it, tranced and still!
column24: Their scant ranks crown the pale, round, pasture-hill,     And watch, far down, the austere waters run     Their circuit thro’ the serious marshes dun.
column25: No bird-call stirs the blue; but strangely thrill       The blunt-faced, brown cicada’s wing-notes shrill,     A web of silver o’er the silence spun.
column26: O zithern-winged musician, whence it came,       I wonder, this insistent song of thine!
column27: Did once the highest string of Summer’s lyre,     Snapt on some tense chord slender as a flame,       Take form again in these vibrations fine       That o’er the tranquil spheres of noon aspire?
column28: _IN SEPTEMBER_     This windy, bright September afternoon       My heart is wide awake, yet full of dreams.
column29: The air, alive with hushed confusion, teems     With scent of grain-fields, and a mystic rune,     Foreboding of the fall of Summer soon,       Keeps swelling and subsiding; till there seems       O’er all the world of valleys, hills, and streams,     Only the wind’s inexplicable tune.
column30: My heart is full of dreams, yet wide awake.
column31: I lie and watch the topmost tossing boughs       Of tall elms, pale against the vaulted blue;     But even now some yellowing branches shake,       Some hue of death the living green endows:--       If beauty flies, fain would I vanish too.
column32: _A VESPER SONNET_     This violet eve is like a waveless stream       Celestial, from the rapt horizon’s brink,       Assuaging day with the diviner drink     Of temperate ecstasy, and dews, and dream.
column33: The wine-warm dusks, that brim the valley, gleam       With here and there a lonely casement.
column34: Cease       The impetuous purples from the sky of peace,     Like God’s mood in tranquillity supreme.
column35: The encircling uplands east and west lie clear       In thin aërial amber, threaded fine,--     Where bush-fires gnaw the bramble-thickets sere,--       With furtive scarlet.
column36: Through the hush benign     One white-throat voices, till the stars appear,       The benediction of the Thought Divine.
column37: _THE POTATO HARVEST_     A high bare field, brown from the plough, and borne       Aslant from sunset; amber wastes of sky       Washing the ridge; a clamour of crows that fly     In from the wide flats where the spent tides mourn     To yon their rocking roosts in pines wind-torn;       A line of grey snake-fence, that zigzags by       A pond, and cattle; from the homestead nigh     The long deep summonings of the supper horn.
column38: Black on the ridge, against that lonely flush,       A cart, and stoop-necked oxen; ranged beside       Some barrels; and the day-worn harvest-folk,     Here emptying their baskets, jar the hush       With hollow thunders.
column39: Down the dusk hillside       Lumbers the wain; and day fades out like smoke.
column40: _THE OAT-THRESHING_     A little brown old homestead, bowered in trees       That o’er the Autumn landscape shine afar,       Burning with amber and with cinnabar.
column41: A yellow hillside washed in airy seas     Of azure, where the swallow drops and flees.
column42: Midway the slope, clear in the beaming day,       A barn by many seasons beaten grey,     Big with the gain of prospering husbandries.
column43: In billows round the wide red welcoming doors       High piles the golden straw; while from within,       Where plods the team amid the chaffy din,     The loud pulsation of the thresher soars,       Persistent as if earth could not let cease       This happy proclamation of her peace.
column44: _THE AUTUMN THISTLES_     The morning sky is white with mist, the earth       White with the inspiration of the dew.
column45: The harvest light is on the hills anew,     And cheer in the grave acres’ fruitful girth.
column46: Only in this high pasture is there dearth,       Where the gray thistles crowd in ranks austere,       As if the sod, close-cropt for many a year,     Brought only bane and bitterness to birth.
column47: But in the crisp air’s amethystine wave       How the harsh stalks are washed with radiance now,       How gleams the harsh turf where the crickets lie     Dew-freshened in their burnished armour brave!
column48: Since earth could not endure nor heaven allow       Aught of unlovely in the morn’s clear eye.
column49: _INDIAN SUMMER_     What touch hath set the breathing hills afire       With amethyst, to quench them with a tear       Of ecstasy?
column50: These common fields appear     The consecrated home of hopes past number.
column51: So many visions, so entranced a slumber,       Such dreams possess the noonday’s luminous sphere,       That earth, content with knowing Heaven so near,     Hath done with aspiration and desire.
column52: In these unlooked-for hours of Truth’s clear reign       Unjarring fitness hath surprised our strife.
column53: This radiance, that might seem to cheat the view     With loveliness too perfect to be true,       But shows this vexed and self-delusive life       Ideals whereto our Real must attain.
column54: _THE PUMPKINS IN THE CORN_     Amber and blue, the smoke behind the hill,       Where in the glow fades out the Morning Star,       Curtains the Autumn cornfield, sloped afar,     And strikes an acrid savour on the chill.
column55: The hilltop fence shines saffron o’er the still       Unbending ranks of bunched and bleaching corn       And every pallid stalk is crisp with morn,     Crisp with the silver Autumn morn’s distil.
column56: Purple the narrowing alleys stretched between       The spectral shooks, a purple harsh and cold,       But spotted, where the gadding pumpkins run,     With bursts of blaze that startle the serene       Like sudden voices,--globes of orange bold,       Elate to mimic the unrisen sun.
column57: _THE WINTER FIELDS_     Winds here, and sleet, and frost that bites like steel.
column58: The low bleak hill rounds under the low sky.
column59: Naked of flock and fold the fallows lie,     Thin streaked with meagre drift.
column60: The gusts reveal     By fits the dim grey snakes of fence, that steal       Through the white dusk.
column61: The hill-foot poplars sigh,       While storm and death with winter trample by,     And the iron fields ring sharp, and blind lights reel.
column62: Yet in the lonely ridges, wrenched with pain,       Harsh solitary hillocks, bound and dumb,     Grave glebes close-lipped beneath the scourge and chain,       Lurks hid the germ of ecstasy--the sum     Of life that waits on summer, till the rain       Whisper in April and the crocus come.
column63: _IN AN OLD BARN_     Tons upon tons the brown-green fragrant hay       O’erbrims the mows beyond the time-warped eaves,       Up to the rafters where the spider weaves,     Though few flies wander his secluded way.
column64: Through a high chink one lonely golden ray,       Wherein the dust is dancing, slants unstirred.
column65: In the dry hush some rustlings light are heard,     Of winter-hidden mice at furtive play.
column66: Far down, the cattle in their shadowed stalls,       Nose-deep in clover fodder’s meadowy scent,       Forget the snows that whelm their pasture streams,     The frost that bites the world beyond their walls.
column67: Warm housed, they dream of summer, well content       In day-long contemplation of their dreams.
column68: _MIDWINTER THAW_     How shrink the snows upon this upland field,       Under the dove-grey dome of brooding noon!
column69: They shrink with soft, reluctant shocks, and soon     In sad brown ranks the furrows lie revealed.
column70: From radiant cisterns of the frost unsealed       Now wakes through all the air a watery rune--       The babble of a million brooks atune,     In fairy conduits of blue ice concealed.
column71: Noisy with crows, the wind-break on the hill       Counts o’er its buds for summer.
column72: In the air     Some shy foreteller prophesies with skill--       Some voyaging ghost of bird, some effluence rare;     And the stall-wearied cattle dream their fill       Of deep June pastures where the pools are fair.
column73: _THE FLIGHT OF THE GEESE_     I hear the low wind wash the softening snow,       The low tide loiter down the shore.
column74: The night       Full filled with April forecast, hath no light.
column75: The salt wave on the sedge-flat pulses slow.
column76: Through the hid furrows lisp in murmurous flow       The thaw’s shy ministers; and hark!
column77: The height       Of heaven grows weird and loud with unseen flight     Of strong hosts prophesying as they go!
column78: High through the drenched and hollow night their wings       Beat northward hard on winter’s trail.
column79: The sound     Of their confused and solemn voices, borne     Athwart the dark to their long Arctic morn,       Comes with a sanction and an awe profound,     A boding of unknown, foreshadowed things.
column80: _IN THE WIDE AWE AND WISDOM OF THE NIGHT_     In the wide awe and wisdom of the night       I saw the round world rolling on its way,     Beyond significance of depth or height,       Beyond the interchange of dark and day.
column81: I marked the march to which is set no pause,       And that stupendous orbit, round whose rim     The great sphere sweeps, obedient unto laws       That utter the eternal thought of Him.
column82: I compassed time, outstripped the starry speed,       And in my still soul apprehended space,     Till, weighing laws which these but blindly heed,       At last I came before Him face to face,--     And knew the Universe of no such span     As the august infinitude of Man.
column83: _THE HERRING WEIR_     Back to the green deeps of the outer bay       The red and amber currents glide and cringe,       Diminishing behind a luminous fringe     Of cream-white surf and wandering wraiths of spray.
column84: Stealthily, in the old reluctant way,       The red flats are uncovered, mile on mile,       To glitter in the sun a golden while.
column85: Far down the flats, a phantom sharply gray,     The herring weir emerges, quick with spoil.
column87: Then draws near,       Descending from the farm-house on the height,     A cart, with gaping tubs.
column88: The oxen toil       Sombrely o’er the level to the weir,       And drag a long black trail across the light.
column89: _BLOMIDON_     This is that black rock bastion, based in surge,       Pregnant with agate and with amethyst,     Whose foot the tides of storied Minas scourge,       Whose top austere withdraws into its mist.
column90: This is that ancient cape of tears and storm,       Whose towering front inviolable frowns     O’er vales Evangeline and love keep warm--       Whose fame thy song, O tender singer, crowns.
column91: Yonder, across these reeling fields of foam,       Came the sad threat of the avenging ships.
column92: What profit now to know if just the doom,       Though harsh!
column93: The streaming eyes, the praying lips,     The shadow of inextinguishable pain,     The poet’s deathless music--these remain!
column94: _THE NIGHT SKY_     O deep of Heaven, ’tis thou alone art boundless,       ’Tis thou alone our balance shall not weigh,     ’Tis thou alone our fathom-line finds soundless,--       Whose infinite our finite must obey!
column95: Through thy blue realms and down thy starry reaches       Thought voyages forth beyond the furthest fire,     And, homing from no sighted shoreline, teaches       Thee measureless as is the soul’s desire.
column96: O deep of Heaven, no beam of Pleiad ranging       Eternity may bridge thy gulf of spheres!
column97: The ceaseless hum that fills thy sleep unchanging       Is rain of the innumerable years.
column98: Our worlds, our suns, our ages, these but stream     Through thine abiding like a dateless dream.
column99: _TIDES_     Through the still dusk how sighs the ebb-tide out       Reluctant for the reed-beds!
column102: Beyond the wan grey strand’s     Low limits how the winding channels grieve,     Aware the evasive waters soon will leave       Them void amid the waste of desolate lands,       Where shadowless to the sky the marsh expands,     And the noon heats must scar them, and the drought.
column103: Yet soon for them the solacing tide returns       To quench their thirst of longing.
column104: Ah, not so     Works the stern law our tides of life obey!
column105: Ebbing in the night watches swift away,       Scarce known are fled for ever is the flow;     And in parched channel still the shrunk stream mourns.
column106: _THE DESERTED CITY_     There lies a little city leagues away.
column107: Its wharves the green sea washes all day long.
column108: Its busy, sun-bright wharves with sailors’ song     And clamour of trade ring loud the live-long day.
column109: Into the happy harbour hastening, gay       With press of snowy canvas, tall ships throng.
column110: The peopled streets to blithe-eyed Peace belong,     Glad housed beneath these crowding roofs of grey.
column111: ’Twas long ago this city prospered so,       For yesterday a woman died therein.
column112: Since when the wharves are idle fallen, I know,       And in the streets is hushed the pleasant din;       The thronging ships have been, the songs have been;--     Since yesterday it is so long ago.
column113: _DARK_     Now, for the night is hushed and blind with rain,       My soul desires communion, Dear, with thee.
column114: But hour by hour my spirit gets not free,--     Hour by still hour my longing strives in vain.
column115: The thick dark hems me, even to the restless brain.
column116: The wind’s confusion vague encumbers me.
column117: Even passionate memory, grown too faint to see     Thy features, stirs not in her straitening chain.
column118: And thou, dost thou too feel this strange divorce       Of will from power?
column119: The spell of night and wind,       Baffling desire and dream, dost thou too find?
column120: Not distance parts us, Dear; but this dim force,       Intangible, holds us helpless, hushed with pain,       Dumb with the dark, blind with the gusts of rain!
column121: _RAIN_     Sharp drives the rain, sharp drives the endless rain.
column122: The rain-winds wake and wander, lift and blow.
column123: The slow smoke-wreaths of vapour to and fro,     Wave and unweave and gather and build again.
column124: Over the far gray reaches of the plain,--       Grey miles on miles my passionate thought must go,--       I strain my sight, grown dim with gazing so,     Pressing my face against the streaming pane.
column127: If love had power       To voice its utmost yearning, even tho’       Through time and bitter distance, not in vain,     Surely her heart would hear me at this hour,       Look through the years, and see!
column128: But would she know       The white face pressed against the streaming pane?
column129: _MIST_     Its hand compassionate guards our restless sight       Against how many a harshness, many an ill!
column130: Tender as sleep, its shadowy palms distil     Weird vapours that ensnare our eyes with light.
column131: Rash eyes, kept ignorant in their own despite,       It lets not see the unsightliness they will,       But paints each scanty fairness fairer still,     And still deludes us to our own delight.
column132: It fades, regathers, never quite dissolves.
column135: that the heart and brain       Might keep their mist and glamour, not to know     So soon the disenchantment and the pain!
column136: But one by one our dear illusions go,       Stript and cast forth as time’s slow wheel revolves.
column137: _MOONLIGHT_     The fifers of these amethystine fields,       Whose far fine sound the night makes musical,       Now while thou wak’st and longing would’st recall     Joys that no rapture of remembrance yields,     Voice to thy soul, lone-sitting deep within       The still recesses of thine ecstasy,       My love and my desire, that fain would fly     With this far-silvering moon and fold thee in.
column138: But not for us the touch, the clasp, the kiss,       And for our restlessness no rest.
column139: In vain       These aching lips, these hungering hearts that strain     Toward the denied fruition of our bliss,       Had love not learned of longing to devise       Out of desire and dream our paradise.
column140: O SOLITARY OF THE AUSTERE SKY     O solitary of the austere sky,       Pale presence of the unextinguished star,     That from thy station where the spheres wheel by,       And quietudes of infinite patience are,     Watchest this wet, grey-visaged world emerge,--       Cold pinnacle on pinnacle, and deep     On deep of ancient wood and wandering surge,--       Out of the silence and the mists of sleep;     How small am I in thine august regard!
column141: Invisible,--and yet I know my worth!
column142: When comes the hour to break this ’prisoning shard,       And reunite with Him that breathed me forth,     Then shall this atom of the Eternal Soul     Encompass thee in its benign control!
column143: _AUTOCHTHON_           I       I am the spirit astir         To swell the grain       When fruitful suns confer         With labouring rain;       I am the life that thrills         In branch and bloom;     I am the patience of abiding hills,         The promise masked in doom.
column144: II       When the sombre lands are wrung,         And storms are out,       And giant woods give tongue,         I am the shout;       And when the earth would sleep,         Wrapped in her snows,     I am the infinite gleam of eyes that keep         The post of her repose.
column145: III       I am the hush of calm,         I am the speed,       The flood-tide’s triumphing psalm,         The marsh-pool’s heed;       I work in the rocking roar         Where cataracts fall;     I flash in the prismy fire that dances o’er         The dew’s ephemeral ball.
column146: IV       I am the voice of wind         And wave and tree,       Of stern desires and blind,         Of strength to be;       I am the cry by night         At point of dawn,     The summoning bugle from the unseen height,         In cloud and doubt withdrawn.
column147: V       I am the strife that shapes         The stature of man,       The pang no hero escapes,         The blessing, the ban;       I am the hammer that moulds         The iron of our race,     The omen of God in our blood that a people beholds,         The foreknowledge veiled in our face.
column150: I see thy cool green plains afar.
column151: Thy dykes where grey sea-grasses are,         Mine eyes behold them yet.
column152: But not the gladness breathed of old     Thy bordering, blue hill-hollows hold;     Thy wind-blown leagues of green unrolled,         Thy flats the red floods fret,     Thy steady-streaming winds--no more     These work the rapture wrought of yore,     When all thy wide bright strength outbore         My soul from fleshly bar.
column153: A darkness as of drifted rain     Is over tide, and dyke, and plain.
column154: The shadow-pall of human pain         Is fallen on Tantramar.
column155: II     A little garden gay with phlox,     Blue corn-flowers, yellow hollyhocks,     Red poppies, pink and purple stocks,         Looks over Tantramar.
column156: Pale yellow drops the road before     The hospitable cottage-door,--     A yellow, upland road, and o’er     The green marsh seeks the low red shore         And winding dykes afar.
column157: Beyond the marsh, and miles away,     The great tides of the tumbling bay     Swing glittering in the golden day,         Swing foaming to and fro;     And nearer, in a nest of green,     A little turbid port is seen,     Where pitch-black fishing-boats careen,         Left when the tide runs low.
column158: The little port is safe and fit.
column159: About its wharf the plover flit,     The grey net-reels loom over it,         With grass about their feet.
column160: In wave and storm it hath no part,     This harbour in the marshes’ heart;     Behind its dykes, at peace, apart         It hears the surges beat.
column161: The garden hollyhocks are tall;     They tower above the garden wall,     And see, far down, the port, and all         The creeks, and marshes wide;     But Margery, Margery,     ’Tis something further thou wouldst see!
column162: Bid all thy blooms keep watch with thee         Across the outmost tide.
column163: Bid them keep wide their starry eyes     To warn thee should a white sail rise,     Slow climbing up, from alien skies,         The azure round of sea.
column164: He sails beneath a stormy star;     The waves are wild, the Isles afar;     Summer is ripe on Tantramar,         And yet returns not he.
column165: Long, long thine eyes have watched in vain,     Waited in fear, and wept again.
column166: Is it no more than lover’s pain         That makes thy heart so wild?
column167: At dreams within the cottage door     The old man’s eyes are lingering o’er     The little port,--the far-off shore,--         His dear and only child.
column168: And at her spinning-wheel within     The mother’s hands forget to spin.
column169: With loving voice she calls thee in,--         Her dear and only child.
column170: To leave the home-dear hearts to ache     Was not for thee, though thine should break.
column171: For their dear sake, for their dear sake,         Thou wouldst not go with him.
column172: But always wise, and strong, and free,     Is given to which of us to be?--     A gathering shadow, Margery,         Makes all thy daylight dim!
column173: Yet surely soon will break the day     For which thine anxious waitings pray,--     His sails, athwart the yellow bay,         Shall cleave the sky’s blue rim.
column174: III     To-night the wind roars in from sea;     The crow clings in the straining tree;     Curlew and crane and bittern flee         The dykes of Tantramar.
column175: To-night athwart an inky sky     A narrowing sun dropped angrily,     Scoring the gloom with dreadful dye,         A bitter and flaming scar.
column176: But ere night falls, across the tide     A close-reefed barque has been descried,     And word goes round the country-side--         ‘The “Belle” is in the bay!’     And ere the loud night closes down     Upon that light’s terrific frown,     Along the dyke, with blowing gown,         She takes her eager way.
column177: Just where his boat will haste to land,     On the open wharf she takes her stand.
column178: Her pale hair blows from out its band.
column179: She does not heed the storm.
column180: Her blinding joy of heart they know     Who so have fared, and waited so.
column181: She heeds not what the winds that blow;         She does not feel the storm.
column183: The night     With cloud grows black, with foam gleams white     The creek boils to its utmost height.
column185: The gale shouts in the outer waves     Amid a world of gaping graves;     Against the dyke each great surge raves,         Blind battering like a bull.
column188: The brute sea shakes     The sheltering wall.
column190: The sharp salt whips her face, and wakes         The dreamer from her dream.
column193: The broad marsh foams, and sinks.
column194: The din     Of waves is where her world has been;--         Is this--is this the dream?
column195: ---- One moment in that surging hell     The old wharf shook, then cringed and fell.
column196: ---- Then came a lonely hulk, the ‘Belle,’         And drove athwart the waste.
column197: *       *       *       *       *     They know no light, nor any star,     Those ruined plains of Tantramar.
column198: And where the maid and lover are         They know nor fear nor haste.
column199: IV     After the flood on Tantramar     The fisher-folk flocked in from far.
column200: They stopped the breach; they healed the scar.
column201: Once more the marsh grew green.
column202: But at the marsh’s inmost edge,     Where a tall fringe of flag and sedge     Catches a climbing hawthorn hedge,         A lonely hulk is seen.
column203: It lies forgotten of all tides,     The grass grows round its bleaching sides,     An endless inland peace abides         About its mouldering age.
column204: But in the cot-door on the height     An old man sits with fading sight,     And memories of one cruel night         Are all his heritage.
column205: And at her spinning-wheel within     The mother’s hands forget to spin,--     So weary all her days have been         Since Margery went away.
column208: Until that sorrow fades afar,     Thy plains where birds and blossoms are         Laugh not their ancient way!
column209: _THE VALLEY OF THE WINDING WATER_     The valley of the winding water       Wears the same light it wore of old,     Still o’er the purple peaks the portals       Of distance and desire unfold.
column210: Still break the fields of opening June       To emerald in their ancient way.
column211: The sapphire of the summer heaven       Is infinite, as yesterday.
column212: My eyes are on the greening earth,       The exultant bobolinks wild awing;     And yet, of all this kindly gladness,       My heart beholds not anything.
column213: For in a still room far away,       With mourners round her silent head,     Blind to the quenchless tears, the anguish--       I see, to-day, a woman dead.
column214: _MARSYAS_     A little grey hill-glade, close-turfed, withdrawn     Beyond resort or heed of trafficking feet,     Ringed round with slim trunks of the mountain ash.
column215: Through the slim trunks and scarlet bunches flash--     Beneath the clear chill glitterings of the dawn dawn--     Far off, the crests, where down the rosy shore     The Pontic surges beat.
column217: The thin airs wash     The circuit of the autumn-coloured hills,     And this high glade, whereon     The satyr pipes, who soon shall pipe no more.
column218: He sits against the beech-tree’s mighty bole,--     He leans, and with persuasive breathing fills     The happy shadows of the slant-set lawn.
column219: The goat-feet fold beneath a gnarlèd root;     And sweet, and sweet the note that steals and thrills     From slender stops of that shy flute.
column220: Then to the goat-feet comes the wide-eyed fawn     Hearkening; the rabbits fringe the glade, and lay     Their long ears to the sound;     In the pale boughs the partridge gather round,     And quaint hern from the sea-green river reeds;     The wild ram halts upon a rocky horn     O’erhanging; and, unmindful of his prey,     The leopard steals with narrowed lids to lay     His spotted length along the ground.
column221: The thin airs wash, the thin clouds wander by,     And those hushed listeners move not.
column222: All the morn     He pipes, soft-swaying, and with half-shut eye,     In rapt content of utterance,--                                     nor heeds     The young God standing in his branchy place,     The languor on his lips, and in his face,     Divinely inaccessible, the scorn.
column223: _THE FORTRESS_     While raves the midnight storm,     And roars the rain upon the windy roof,     Heart held to heart and all the world aloof,     We laugh secure and warm.
column224: This chamber of our bliss     Might seem a fortress by a haunted main,     Which shouting hosts embattled charge in vain,     Powerless to mar our kiss.
column225: O life, O storm of years,     Our walls are built against your shattering siege;     Our dwelling is with Love, our sovereign liege,     And fenced from change and tears.
column226: _SEVERANCE_     The tide falls, and the night falls,       And the wind blows in from the sea,     And the bell on the bar it calls and calls,       And the wild hawk cries from his tree.
column227: The late crane calls to his fellows gone       In long flight over the sea,     And my heart with the crane flies on and on,       Seeking its rest and thee     O Love, the tide returns to the strand,       And the crane flies back oversea,     But he brings not my heart from his far-off land,       For he brings not thee to me.
column228: _EPITAPH FOR A SAILOR BURIED ASHORE_     He who but yesterday would roam       Careless as clouds and currents range,     In homeless wandering most at home,       Inhabiter of change;     Who wooed the west to win the east,       And named the stars of North and South,     And felt the zest of Freedom’s feast       Familiar in his mouth;     Who found a faith in stranger-speech,       And fellowship in foreign hands,     And had within his eager reach       The relish of all lands--     How circumscribed a plot of earth       Keeps now his restless footsteps still,     Whose wish was wide as ocean’s girth,       Whose will the water’s will!
column229: _THE SILVER THAW_     There came a day of showers       Upon the shrinking snow;     The south wind sighed of flowers,       The softening skies hung low.
column230: Midwinter for a space     Foreshadowing April’s face,     The white world caught the fancy,       And would not let it go.
column231: In reawakened courses       The brooks rejoiced the land;     We dreamed the Spring’s shy forces       Were gathering close at hand.
column232: The dripping buds were stirred,     As if the sap had heard     The long-desired persuasion       Of April’s soft command.
column233: But antic Time had cheated       With hope’s elusive gleam;     The phantom Spring, defeated,       Fled down the ways of dream.
column234: And in the night the reign     Of winter came again,     With frost upon the forest       And stillness on the stream.
column235: When morn in rose and crocus       Came up the bitter sky,     Celestial beams awoke us       To wondering ecstasy.
column236: The wizard Winter’s spell     Had wrought so passing well,     That earth was bathed in glory,       As if God’s smile were nigh.
column237: The silvered saplings, bending,       Flashed in a rain of gems;     The statelier trees, attending,       Blazed in their diadems.
column238: White fire and amethyst     All common things had kissed,     And chrysolites and sapphires       Adorned the bramble-stems.
column239: In crystalline confusion       All beauty came to birth;     It was a kind illusion       To comfort waiting earth--     To bid the buds forget     The Spring so distant yet,     And hearts no more remember       The iron season’s dearth.
column240: _THE LILY OF THE VALLEY_     Did Winter, letting fall in vain regret       A tear among the tender leaves of May,     Embalm the tribute, lest she might forget,       In this elect, imperishable way?
column241: Or did the virgin Spring sweet vigil keep       In the white radiance of the midnight hour,     And whisper to the unwondering ear of Sleep       Some shy desire that turned into a flower?
column242: _THE NIGHT-HAWK_     When frogs make merry the pools of May,             And sweet, oh sweet,             Through the twilight dim             Is the vesper hymn     Their myriad mellow pipes repeat       As the rose-dusk dies away.
column245: With melting skies o’er him,       All summer before him,       His wild brown mate to adore him,         By the spell of his power         He summons the apples in flower.
column246: In the high pale heaven he flits and calls;             Then swift, oh swift,             On sounding wing             That hums like a string,     To the quiet glades where the gnat-clouds drift       And the night-moths flicker, he falls.
column249: With melting skies o’er him,       All summer before him,       His wild brown mate to adore him,         By the spell of his power         He summons the apples in flower.
column250: _THE HERMIT-THRUSH_     Over the tops of the trees,       And over the shallow stream,     The shepherd of sunset frees       The amber phantoms of dream.
column251: The time is the time of vision;       The hour is the hour of calm;     Hark!
column252: On the stillness Elysian       Breaks how divine a psalm!
column253: _Oh, clear in the sphere of the air,           Clear, clear, tender and far,         Our aspiration of prayer           Unto eve’s clear star!_     O singer serene, secure!
column254: From thy throat of silver and dew     What transport lonely and pure,       Unchanging, endlessly new,--     An unremembrance of mirth,       And a contemplation of tears,     As if the musing of earth       Communed with the dreams of the years!
column255: _Oh, clear in the sphere of the air,           Clear, clear, tender and far,         Our aspiration of prayer           Unto eve’s clear star!_     O cloistral ecstatic!
column256: thy cell       In the cool green aisles of the leaves     Is the shrine of a power by whose spell       Whoso hears aspires and believes!
column258: thine hour       Is the sacrament of desire,     When love hath a heavenlier flower,       And passion a holier fire!
column259: _Oh, clear in the sphere of the air,           Clear, clear, tender and far,         Our aspiration of prayer           Unto eve’s clear star!_           _THE WILD-ROSE THICKET_     Where humming flies frequent, and where     Pink petals open to the air,     The wild-rose thicket seems to be     The summer in epitome.
column260: Amid its gold-green coverts meet     The late dew and the noonday heat;     Around it, to the sea-rim harsh,     The patient levels of the marsh;     And o’er it the pale heavens bent,     Half sufferance and half content.
column261: _MY TREES_     At evening, when the winds are still,       And wide the yellowing landscape glows,     My firwoods on the lonely hill       Are crowned with sun and loud with crows.
column262: Their flocks throng down the open sky       From far salt flats and sedgy seas;     Then dusk and dewfall quench the cry,--       So calm a home is in my trees.
column263: At morning, when the young wind swings       The green slim tops and branches high,     Out puffs a noisy whirl of wings,       Dispersing up the empty sky.
column264: In this dear refuge no roof stops       The skyward pinion winnowing through.
column265: My trees shut out the world;--their tops       Are open to the infinite blue.
column266: _THE HAWKBIT_     How sweetly on the Autumn scene,     When haws are red amid the green,     The hawkbit shines with face of cheer,     The favourite of the faltering year!
column267: When days grow short and nights grow cold     How fairly gleams its eye of gold,     On pastured field and grassy hill,     Along the roadside and the rill!
column268: It seems the spirit of a flower,     This offspring of the Autumn hour,     Wandering back to earth to bring     Some kindly afterthought of Spring.
column269: A dandelion’s ghost might so     Amid Elysian meadows blow,     Become more fragile and more fine     Breathing the atmosphere divine.
column270: _GREY ROCKS AND GREYER SEA_     Grey rocks, and greyer sea,       And surf along the shore--     And in my heart a name       My lips shall speak no more.
column271: The high and lonely hills       Endure the darkening year--     And in my heart endure       A memory and a tear.
column272: Across the tide a sail       That tosses, and is gone--     And in my heart the kiss       That longing dreams upon.
column273: Grey rocks, and greyer sea,       And surf along the shore--     And in my heart the face       That I shall see no more.
column274: _A SONG OF CHEER_     The winds are up with wakening day       And tumult in the tree;     Across the cool and open sky       White clouds are streaming free;     The new light breaks o’er flood and field       Clear like an echoing horn,     While in loud flight the crows are blown       Athwart the sapphire morn.
column275: What tho’ the maple’s scarlet flame       Declares the summer done,     Tho’ finch and starling voyage south       To win a softer sun,     What tho’ the withered leaf whirls by       To strew the purpling stream,--     Stretched are the world’s glad veins with strength,       Despair is grown a dream!
column276: The acres of the golden rod       Are glorious on the hills.
column277: Tho storm and loss approach, the year’s       High heart upleaps and thrills.
column278: Dearest, the cheer, the brave delight,       Are given to shame regret,     That when the long frost falls, our hearts       Be glad, and not forget!
column279: _A SONG OF GROWTH_     In the heart of a man       Is a thought upfurled,     Reached its full span       It shakes the world,     And to one high thought     Is a whole race wrought.
column280: Not with vain noise       The great work grows,     Nor with foolish voice,       But in repose,--     Not in the rush     But in the hush.
column281: From the cogent lash       Of the cloud-herd wind     The low clouds dash,       Blown headlong, blind;     But beyond, the great blue     Looks moveless through.
column282: O’er the loud world sweep       The scourge and the rod;     But in deep beyond deep       Is the stillness of God;--     At the Fountains of Life     No cry, no strife.
column283: _TO G. B. R._     How merry sings the aftermath,       With crickets fifing in the dew!
column284: The home-sweet sounds, the scene, the hour,       I consecrate to you.
column285: All this you knew and loved with me;       All this in our delight had part;     And now--though us earth sees no more       As comrades, heart to heart--     This kindly strength of open fields,       This faith of eve, this calm of air,     They lift my spirit close to you       In memory and prayer.
column286: _THE BIRD’S SONG, THE SUN, AND THE WIND_     The bird’s song, the sun, and the wind--       The wind that rushes, the sun that is still,     The song of the bird that sings alone,       And wide light washing the lonely hill!
column287: The Spring’s coming, the buds and the brooks--       The brooks that clamour, the buds in the rain,     The coming of Spring that comes unprayed for,       And eyes that welcome it not for pain!
column288: _OH, PURPLE HANG THE PODS_     Oh, purple hang the pods       On the green locust-tree,     And yellow turn the sods       On a grave that’s dear to me!
column289: And blue, softly blue,       The hollow Autumn sky,     With its birds flying through       To where the sun-lands lie!
column290: In the sun-lands they’ll bide       While Winter’s on the tree;--     And oh that I might hide       The grave that’s dear to me!
column291: _BRINGING HOME THE COWS_     When potatoes were in blossom,       When the new hay filled the mows,     Sweet the paths we trod together,       Bringing home the cows.
column292: What a purple kissed the pasture,       Kissed and blessed the alder-boughs,     As we wandered slow at sundown,       Bringing home the cows!
column293: How the far-off hills were gilded       With the light that dream allows,     As we built our hopes beyond them,       Bringing home the cows!
column294: How our eyes were bright with visions,       What a meaning wreathed our brows,     As we watched the cranes, and lingered,       Bringing home the cows!
column295: Past the years, and through the distance,       Throbs the memory of our vows,     Oh that we again were children       Bringing home the cows!
column296: _THE KEEPERS OF THE PASS_ [When the Iroquois were moving in overwhelming force to obliterate the infant town of Montreal, Adam Daulac and a small band of comrades, binding themselves by oath not to return alive, went forth to meet the enemy in a distant pass between the Ottawa river and the hills.
column297: There they died to a man, but not till they had slain so many of the savages that the invading force was shattered and compelled to withdraw.]

column299: No more for us shall burn     The pine-logs on the happy hearth,       For we shall not return.
column300: We’ve come to our last camping-ground.
column301: Set axe to fir and tamarack.
column302: The foe is here, the end is near,       And we shall not turn back.
column303: In vain for us the town shall wait,       The home-dear faces yearn,     The watchers on the steeple watch,--       For we shall not return.
column304: For them we’re come to these hard straits,       To save from flame and wrack     The little city built far off;       And we shall not turn back.
column305: Now beat the yelling butchers down.
column306: Let musket blaze, and axe-edge burn.
column307: Set hand to hand, lay brand to brand,       But we shall not return.
column308: For every man of us that falls       Their hordes a score shall lack.
column309: Close in about the Lily Flag!
column310: No man of us goes back.
column311: For us no morrow’s dawn shall break.
column312: Our sons and wives shall learn     Some day from lips of flying scout       Why we might not return.
column313: A dream of children’s laughter comes       Across the battle’s slack,     A vision of familiar streets,--       But we shall not go back.
column314: Up roars the painted storm once more.
column315: Long rest we soon shall earn.
column316: Henceforth the city safe may sleep,       But we shall not return.
column317: And when our last has fallen in blood       Between these waters black,     Their tribe shall no more lust for war,--       For we shall not turn back.
column318: In vain for us the town shall wait,       The home-dear faces yearn,     The watchers in the steeple watch,       For we shall not return.
column319: _NEW YEAR’S EVE_ (AFTER THE FRENCH OF FRÉCHETTE)     Ye night winds shaking the weighted boughs       Of snow-blanched hemlock and frosted fir,     While crackles sharply the thin crust under       The passing feet of the wayfarer;     Ye night cries pulsing in long-drawn waves       Where beats the bitter tide to its flood;     A tumult of pain, a rumour of sorrow,       Troubling the starred night’s tranquil mood;     Ye shudderings where, like a great beast bound,       The forest strains to its depths remote;     Be still and hark!
column320: From the high gray tower       The great bell sobs in its brazen throat.
column321: A strange voice out of the pallid heaven,       Twelve sobs it utters, and stops.
column323: ’Tis the ominous _Hail!_ and the stern _Farewell!_       Of Past and Present in passing flight.
column324: This moment, herald of hope and doom,       That cries in our ears and then is gone,     Has marked for us in the awful volume       One step toward the infinite dark--or dawn!
column325: A year is gone, and a year begins.
column326: Ye wise ones, knowing in Nature’s scheme,     Oh tell us whither they go, the years       That drop in the gulfs of time and dream!
column327: They go to the goal of all things mortal,       Where fade our destinies, scarce perceived,     To the dim abyss wherein time confounds them--       The hours we laughed and the days we grieved.
column328: They go where the bubbles of rainbow break       We breathed in our youth of love and fame,     Where great and small are as one together,       And oak and windflower counted the same.
column329: They go where follow our smiles and tears,       The gold of youth and the gray of age,     Where falls the storm and falls the stillness,       The laughter of spring and winter’s rage.
column330: What hand shall gauge the depth of time       Or a little measure eternity?
column331: God only, as they unroll before Him,       Conceives and orders the mystery.
column332: _A CHRISTMAS-EVE COURTIN’_     The snow’d laid deep that winter from the middle of November;     The goin’, as I remember, was the purtiest kind of goin’;     An’ as the time drawed nigh fur turkeys an’ mince pie     The woods, all white an’ frosted, was a sight worth showin’.
column333: The snow hung down the woodpiles all scalloped-like an’ curled.
column334: You’d swear in all the world ther’ warn’t no fences any more.
column335: The cows kep’ under cover, an’ the chickens scratched twice over     The yaller ruck of straw a-layin’ round the stable door.
column336: ’Twas Christmas Eve, in the afternoon, an’ the store was jest a-hummin’     When we seen the parson comin’ in his pung along the road;     An’ as he passed the store he called in through the door,     ‘Church to-night at the Crossroads!
column337: Come, boys, and bring a load!’     ’Twas a new idee in them parts, an’ Bill Simmons made ’n oration     About ‘High Church innovation,’ an’ ‘a-driftin’ back to Rome,’     But I backed the parson’s rights to have Church o’ moonlight nights;     An’ I thought of Nance’s cute red lips, an’ pinted straight fur home.
column338: I wasn’t long a-gittin’ the chores done up, you bet,     An’ the supper that I eat wouldn’t more’n a’ fed a fly!
column339: Then I hitched the mare in the pung an’ soon was bowlin’ along     Down by the crick to Nance’s while the moon was white an’ high.
column340: She didn’t keep me waitin’, fur church was at half-pas’ seven;     An’ my idee of Heaven, as I tucked her into the furs,     Was a-ridin’ with Nance at night when the moon was high an’ white,     An’ the deep sky all a-sparkle like them laughin’ eyes of hers.
column341: I had a heap to say, but I couldn’t jest find my tongue;     But my heart it sung an’ sung, like canaries was into it.
column342: So I chirruped to the mare with a kind of easy air,     An’ Nance had to do the talkin’,--as was jest the one could do it!
column343: An’ I could feel her shoulder, kind of comfortin’ an’ warm,     Nestlin’ agin my arm,--sech a sweet an’ cunnin’ shoulder.
column344: My heart was all afire, but I kep’ gittin’ shyer an’ shyer,     An’ wished that I’d been born a leetle sassier an’ bolder.
column345: We come to them there Crossroads ’fore I’d time to say a word;     An’ I reckon as how I heard mighty little of the sarvice.
column346: But ’twas grand to hear Nance sing ‘Glory to the new-born King,’     Tho’ the way the choir folks stared at us, it made me kind of narvous.
column347: I wished the parson’d stop an’ give me another chance     Out there in the night with Nance, under the stars an’ moon;     An’ I vowed I’d have my say in the tidiest kind of way,     An’ she shouldn’t have no more call to think me a blame gossoon.
column348: At last the preachin’ come to an end, an’ the folks all crowded out.
column349: ’Fore I knowed what I was about we was on the road fur home.
column350: But the sky was overcast an’ a thick snow droppin’ fast,     An’ a big wind down from the mountins got a-rantin’ an moanin’ some.
column351: We hadn’t rode two mile when it blowed like all possessed,     An’ at that I kind of guessed we was in fur a ticklish night.
column352: We couldn’t go more’n a walk, an’ Nance she forgot to talk;     Then I jest slipped my arm around her, an’ she never kicked a mite.
column353: Well, now, if the hull blame roof’d blowed off I wouldn’t ’a keered,     But I seen as how Nance was skeered, so I sez, ‘By gracious, Nance,     I guess if we don’t turn, an’ cut back for the Crossroads, durn     The shelter we’ll git to-night by any kind of a chance!’     Then the mare stopped short an’ whinnied, an’ Nance jest said, ‘Oh, Si!’     An’ then commenced to cry, till I felt like cryin’ too;     I forgot about the storm, an’ jest hugged her close an’ warm,     An’ kissed her, an’ kissed her, an’ swore as how I’d be true.
column354: Then Nance she quit her cryin’ an’ said she wastn’t skeered     So long’s she knowed I keered jest a leetle mite fur her;     But she guessed we’d better try an’ git home, an’ ‘by-an’-by     The storm ’ll stop, an’ anyways, it ain’t so very fur!’     My heart was that chock full I couldn’t find a word to say,     But she understood the way that I looked into her eyes!
column355: In buffaler robe an’ rug I wrapped her warm an’ snug,     An’ got out an’ broke the mare a road all the way to Barnes’s Rise.
column356: ’Twas a tallish tramp, I tell you, a-leadin’ that flounderin’ mare     Thro’ snow drifts anywheres from four to six foot deep.
column357: An’ a ‘painter’ now an’ then howled out from his mountin den;     But Nance, she never heered it, fur she must ’a fell to sleep.
column358: It wasn’t fur from mornin’ when we come to Barnes’s Rise,--     An’ I found to my surprise I’d tramped nine mile an’ wasn’t tired.
column359: I was in sech a happy dream it didn’t hardly seem     As the ride had been any tougher’n jest what I’d desired.
column360: It was easier goin’ now, an’ Nance woke up all rosy.
column361: She was sweeter’n any posy as I kissed her at the gate.
column362: The dawn was jest a-growin’ so I wished her a Merry Christmas,     An’ remarked I must be goin’ as it might be gittin’ late!
column363: We was married at the Crossroads jest six weeks from Christmas Eve;     An’ Nance an’ me believe in our parson’s innovations;     We ain’t much skeered o’ Rome, an’ we reckon he can preach some,     An’ we call that evenin’ sarvice a Providential Dispensation.
column364: _THE SUCCOUR OF GLUSKÂP_ (A MICMAC LEGEND)     The happy valley laughed with sun,       The corn grew firm in stalk,     The lodges clustered safe where run       The streams of Peniawk.
column365: The washing-pools and shallows rang       With shout of lads at play;     At corn-hoeing the women sang;       The warriors were away.
column366: The splashed white pebbles on the beach,       The idling paddles, gleamed;     Before the lodge doors, spare of speech,       The old men basked and dreamed.
column367: And when the windless noon grew hot,       And the white sun beat like steel,     In shade about the shimmering pot       They gathered to their meal.
column368: Then from the hills, on flying feet,       A desperate runner came,     With cry that smote the peaceful street,       And slew the peace with shame.
column369: ‘Trapped in the night, and snared in sleep,       Our warriors wake no more!
column370: Up from Wahloos the Mohawks creep--       Their feet are at the door!’     The grey old sachems rose and mocked       The ruin that drew near;     And down the beach the children flocked,       And women wild with fear.
column371: Launched were the red canoes; when, lo!
column372: Beside them Gluskâp stood,     Appearing with his giant bow       From out his mystic wood.
column373: With quiet voice he called them back,       And comforted their fears;     He swore the lodges should not lack,       He dried the children’s tears;     Till sorrowing mothers almost deemed       The desperate runner lied,     And the tired children slept, and dreamed       Their fathers had not died.
column374: That night behind the mystic wood       The Mohawk warriors crept;     A spell went through the solitude       And stilled them, and they slept.
column375: And when the round moon, rising late,       The Hills of Kawlm had crossed,     She saw the camp of Mohawk hate       Swathed in a great white frost.
column376: At morn, behind the mystic wood       Came Gluskâp, bow in hand,     And marked the ice-bound solitude,       And that unwaking band.
column377: But as he gazed his lips grew mild,       For, safe among the dead,     There played a ruddy, laughing child       By a captive mother’s head;     And child and mother, nestling warm,       Scarce knew their foes had died,     As past their sleep the noiseless storm       Of strange death turned aside.
column378: _HOW THE MOHAWKS SET OUT FOR MEDOCTEC_ [When the invading Mohawks captured the outlying Melicite village of Madawaska, they spared two squaws to guide them down stream to the main Melicite town of Medoctec, below Grand Falls.

column380: I     Grows the great deed, though none     Shout to behold it done!
column381: To the brave deed done by night     Heaven testifies in the light     Stealthy and swift as a dream,     Crowding the breast of the stream,     In their paint and plumes of war     And their war-canoes four score,     They are threading the Oolastook,     Where his cradling hills o’erlook.
column382: The branchy thickets hide them;     The unstartled waters guide them.

column384: No more shall the children wake     As the dawns through the hut-door break;     But the dogs, a trembling pack,     With wistful eyes steal back.
column385: And, to pilot the noiseless foe     Through the perilous passes, go     Two women who could not die--     Whom the knife in the dark passed by.

column407: _THE WOOD FROLIC_     The Morning Star was bitter bright, the morning sky was grey;     And we hitched our teams and started for the woods at break of day.
column408: _Oh, the frost is on the forest, and the snow piles high!_     Along the white and winding road the sled-bells jangled keen     Between the buried fences, the billowy drifts between.
column409: _Oh, merry swing the axes, and the bright chips fly!_     So crisp sang the runners, and so swift the horses sped,     That the woods were all about us ere the sky grew red.
column410: _Oh, the frost is on the forest, and the snow piles high!_     The bark hung ragged on the birch, the lichen on the fir,     The lungwort fringed the maple, and grey moss the juniper.
column411: _Oh, merry swing the axes, and the bright chips fly!_     So still the air and chill the air the branches seemed asleep,     But we broke their ancient visions as the axe bit deep.
column412: _Oh, the frost is on the forest, and the snow piles high!_     With the shouts of the choppers and the barking of their blades,     How rang the startled valleys and the rabbit-haunted glades!
column413: _Oh, merry swing the axes, and the bright chips fly!_     The hard wood and the soft wood, we felled them for our use;     And chiefly, for its scented gum, we loved the scaly spruce;         _Oh, the frost is on the forest, and the snow piles high!_     And here and there, with solemn roar, some hoary tree came down,     And we heard the rolling of the years in the thunder of its crown.
column414: _Oh, merry swing the axes, and the bright chips fly!_     So, many a sled was loaded up above the stake-tops soon;     And many a load was at the farm before the horn of noon;         _Oh, the frost is on the forest, and the snow piles high!_     And ere we saw the sundown all yellow through the trees,     The farmyard stood as thick with wood as a buckwheat patch with bees;         _Oh, merry swing the axes, and the bright chips fly!_     And with the last-returning teams, and axes burnished bright,     We left the woods to slumber in the frosty shadowed night.
column415: _Oh, the frost is on the forest, and the snow piles high!_     And then the wide, warm kitchen, with beams across the ceiling,     Thick hung with red-skinned onions, and homely herbs of healing!
column416: _Oh, merry swing the axes, and the bright chips fly!_     The dishes on the dresser-shelves were shining blue and white,     And o’er the loaded table the lamps beamed bright.
column417: _Oh, the frost is on the forest, and the snow piles high!_     Then, how the ham and turkey and the apple-sauce did fly,     The heights of boiled potatoes and the flats of pumpkin-pie!
column418: _Oh, merry swing the axes, and the bright chips fly!_     With bread-and-cheese and doughnuts fit to feed a farm a year!
column419: And we washed them down with tides of tea and oceans of spruce beer.
column420: _Oh, the frost is on the forest, and the snow piles high!_     At last the pipes were lighted and the chairs pushed back,     And Bill struck up a sea-song on a rather risky tack;         _Oh, merry swing the axes, and the bright chips fly!_     And the girls all thought it funny--but they never knew ’twas worse,     For we gagged him with a doughnut at the famous second verse.
column421: _Oh, the frost is on the forest, and the snow piles high!_     Then someone fetched a fiddle, and we shoved away the table,     And ’twas jig and reel and polka just as long as we were able,         _Oh, merry swing the axes, and the bright chips fly!_     Till at last the girls grew sleepy, and we got our coats to go.
column422: We started off with racing-teams and moonlight on the snow;         _Oh, the frost is on the forest, and the snow piles high!_     And soon again the winter world was voiceless as of old,     Alone with all the wheeling stars, and the great white cold.
column423: _Oh, the frost is on the forest, and the snow piles high!_           _CANADIAN STREAMS_     O rivers rolling to the sea     From lands that bear the maple-tree,       How swell your voices with the strain     Of loyalty and liberty!
column424: A holy music, heard in vain     By coward heart and sordid brain,       To whom this strenuous being seems     Naught but a greedy race for gain.
column425: O unsung streams--not splendid themes     Ye lack to fire your patriot dreams!
column426: Annals of glory gild your waves,     Hope freights your tides, Canadian streams!
column427: St. Lawrence, whose wide water laves     The shores that ne’er have nourished slaves!
column430: Thy rapids, Ottawa, proclaim     Where Daulac and his heroes came!
column431: Thy tides, St. John, declare La Tour,     And, later, many a loyal name!
column432: Thou inland stream, whose vales, secure     From storm, Tecumseh’s death made poor!
column433: And thou small water, red with war,     ’Twixt Beaubassin and Beauséjour!
column434: Dread Saguenay, where eagles soar,     What voice shall from the bastioned shore       The tale of Roberval reveal,     Or his mysterious fate deplore?
column435: Annapolis, do thy floods yet feel     Faint memories of Champlain’s keel,       Thy pulses yet the deed repeat     Of Poutrincourt and d’Iberville?
column436: And thou far tide, whose plains now beat     With march of myriad westering feet,       Saskatchewan, whose virgin sod     So late Canadian blood made sweet?
column437: Your bulwark hills, your valleys broad,     Streams where de Salaberry trod,       Where Wolfe achieved, where Brock was slain,--     Their voices are the voice of God!
